intro: Chapmannia somalensis, commonly known as the Somali chapmannia, is a flowering plant native to the dry regions of Somalia. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, upright growth habit. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically clustered in panicles, and its leaves are narrow and grass-like. It is adapted to arid environments, with deep root systems that help it survive in drought conditions. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and potentially endangered species.
